entry.title: Use Freetronics Experimenters Kit to Build Continuously Changing Color RGB Light
entry.content:
The Idea

When I went through all the parts inside Freetronics Experimenters Kit, and when I saw the RGB LED lie inside the kit, I had this idea that this LED continuously changes its color. I had this image in my mind that the color of the RGB LED just changes and never stop.

Demo Video

Because I used iPhone’s camera to capture the video, and the RGB LED is too bright for the camera(even after I set the maximum value of the color to 60 which is pretty low), the beautiful transition from one color to another can be barely seen in the video.

Video Link: http://youtu.be/MyuLrNblgDo

However, you can download the code from the Github repo which is mentioned below and try it on your own Experimenters Kit after you set up the hardware.

Connect the Hardware

Follow instructions of “Project 7:RGB LED” on page 32 in Arduino Experimenters Kit Project Guide.

Github Repo

You can find the source file in this Github repo: https://github.com/NicholasTD07/freetronics

Source file: https://github.com/NicholasTD07/freetronics/blob/master/continuous_changing_color_RGB_LED/continuous_changing_color_RGB_LED.ino

Software

To help people new to programming, I decided that every new version only makes a small change to the older one.

V1 Simple Start

Let’s start with something simple: giving RGB LED a random color when we start the kit.

This snippet of code will setup the pin mode for the pins on RGB LED and give RGB LED a random color, then do nothing since there’s no code inside function loop.

V2 Random Color Every 0.5 Second

Let’s say we want the color of the RGB LED changes every 0.5 second. Then the only change is inside loop function and it should look like this:

As you can see that we almost copied the code in setup. But we call function delay after setting RGB LED to a different color. The delay function “tells the Arduino to stop doing anything until a certain period of time is up.”(copied from Arduino Experimenters Kit Project Guide) That’s why there’s a 0.5 second pause from one change of color to another.

V2.5 Refactoring

This line saying analogWrite(ledPins[thisLed], randomColor()); is repeated twice. It’s duplicated code! I don’t like that.
Let’s do a little bit refactoring here by adding following function setLed.

And changes analogWrite(ledPins[thisLed], randomColor()); to setLed(ledPins[thisLed], randomColor());.

You might wonder: “It’s still duplicated code. How’s this better?”


First of all, it gives the duplicated code a name. Without a proper name, meaning of a block of a code maybe not that obvious as it is to you to others reading your code.
Second of all, it cut down our code which depends on other code. This can be handy. Let’s say function analogWrite was renamed to writeToAnalog, then with this refactored code, you only need to make this change once.

(If you come up with something else why this refactoring is good, please feel free to leave me a comment. :D)

V3 Add Transition Between One Color to Another

Now, the color of LED changes periodically. But there’s no transition from one color to another. Let’s add that.

V3.1 Keep Record

First, we need two variables to record current colors and target colors. And we want to generate two sets(since we have Red, Green, and Blue on RGB LED) of random color values, one as LED’s current color, another as the target color.

V3.2 Create The loop

If we want the color changes from one to another gradually, then we need to:

  1. Have 2 sets of color values, one is current, another is the set of target colors. Already done!
  2. Every time only change the color values by a small amount.
  3. Test if current colors match target color once a while.
  4. If they do match, make a new set of target colors.
  5. Last but not least, delay for a while. Otherwise the LED will change its color like crazy. :P

Translate those into code, (replace your function loop with this one)

It won’t compile/upload. Because these functions do not exist yet. We are going to write it now. Why don’t we write those functions first?

From my own experience, when a process can be easily decomposed into smaller steps, I prefer Top-down design(decomposition). With Top-down design, I think, one advantage is that you won’t be overwhelmed by the details since every time you are only going one level deeper. Every time I only need to think about one level of the whole problem. And I know all the upper levels are already solved and all the lower levels will be solved but, hey, they are NOT my problems NOW. :D

If you don’t know what Top down design or decomposition means, I recommend watching Lecture 3 of Programming Methodology by Stanford University to get a basic understanding of Top down design and decomposition. Video Link: http://youtu.be/C5HeRliZ0Ns?t=13m Hope you enjoy. Whether you like it or not, if you want to share anything just leave me a comment. :D

For more information, Google Top down design.

V3.3.1 - Implementing currentColorsAreCloseToTargetColors

If anyone of the currentValues aren’t close to the corresponding one in targetValues, then return false which is “not true” in programming language(in this case, we are actually using C++).

P.S. The code in this article is almost using C, except for bool which is a C++ built-in type.

Why not currentValues[thisLed] != targetValues[thisLed]?
What if every time when we change the value, the change is not 1?

V3.3.2 - Implementing colorsAreNotClose

Easy one. No further explanation. :D

V3.4.1 - Implementing updateAllColorsOnLED

The function name is pretty self-explanatory.

Have a look at Output to one pin at a time to find out why we are updating all three colors at the same time.

Why using functions rather than value++; or values[index] += 1; to change the current value?

  1. It has a name which provides a explanation of the code inside.
  2. It’s easier to make change (i.e. adding functionality or changing the step value, the “+1”) while keeping code clean.
  3. When changing the value it needs validation because the value is given to the chip through analogWrite(pin, value), where the value has a maximum value of 255, and a minimum value of 0.

V3.4.2 Functions for updateLedAtIndex

Because of the need to validate value after it is changed, we check the value after increasing and decreasing it. Then give this value to LED.

To be continued.

Possible Pitfalls

Output to one pin at a time

If all the pins on RGB LED don’t get updated at the same time, and values/voltages on some pins don’t get updated, then the actual values/voltages will decrease. And that means if you don’t update the value on one pin, the color will change by itself because of decrease of the voltage on the pin.

Reading Values from OUTPUT pin

At the beginning of Version 3, I once thought, “Hey, why can’t I just get current values of RGB color by reading from the pins and compare those with my target values.”

FAILED.

Here’s why:

The pin mode of LED’s pins are all set to OUTPUT, which means it really just can’t read values IN. Well, I tried and it just doesn’t work this way.

The End

Feel free to ask me anything. :D

P.S.

Since English is not my mother tongue, there could be possible grammar errors and misspelling in this article. And maybe sometimes I couldn’t express what I try to say.

Please feel free to point out anything wrong or . Thanks. :P

entry.title: Fixing Hexo's Deployer
entry.content:
Missing Deployers in Heroku

Some Deployers were not registered when they should be.

TL;DR

In hexo/lib/plugins/deployer/heroku/index.js and .../deployer/openshift.js there’s a line like this:

And, that ../.. is one level deeper than it needs to be.

Case closed. :D

Detailed Version

When I tried to deploy my blog to Heroku, this happened.

So I looked into plugins/console/deploy.js, and I added log.i('deployers: ', deployer); after this block of code.

Then this came up. [info] deployers: { git: [Function], github: [Function] }
That’s when I found that Heroku Deployer was not registered with two other deployers not registered, e.g. openshift, rysnc.

How Hexo Loads All Deployers

As you can see from the log above, somewhere on your disk there’s a folder called node_modules where hexo lies.

When you type hexo deploy, here’s what happens:

TL;DR

  1. hexo/lib/init.js loads everything in hexo/lib/loaders/
  2. hexo/lib/loaders/extend.js loads all Extend/Plugins including our Deployer by doing require('../plugins/' + item);.
  3. hexo/lib/plugins/deployer/index.js registers every deployer by requiring them. (Well, you know, the require in JS).
  4. That’s it.

Detailed Version

  1. hexo/bin/hexo calls hexo/lib/init.js.
  2. init.js loads other important things for Hexo, like config, extend, etc. with this piece of code:
  1. hexo/lib/loaders/extend.js loads Deploy Plugin with this line:

In our case item is the deployer.

  1. At last hexo/lib/plugins/deployer/index.js loads all deployers.

What Went Wrong

In Deployers’ code of Heroku and OpenShift there is a line like this :

Only difference is the different locations of deployer/heroku/index.js and deployer/openshift.js causing the ..\.. part of Heroku is one level deeper than the OpenShift one.

What Really Went Wrong

Yes! The ..\.. part. It is one level deeper than it actually need for both Heroku and OpenShift.

And maybe in that catch statement where I added a line of logging should have something similar there, letting people know what and where is the bug.

What’s More

Though here it says it can, currently Hexo seems couldn’t handle Batch Deployment configuration which looks like this:

entry.title: Hello, Hexo! Good bye, Octopress!
entry.content:
I am leaving Octopress for Hexo.

What is Hexo?

Hexo is a fast, simple and powerful blog framework. It parses your posts with Markdown or other render engine and generates static files with the beautiful theme. All of these just take seconds.

Hexohexo.io/docs/

So, Octopress?

It basically does the same thing. However, it is another framework.

Why Hexo?

  • Better and clearer documentation. See Hexo’s Doc.
    • Explains everything I need to know.
      • How to setup Hexo.
      • Commands.
      • How Hexo works.
      • How to extend Hexo.
      • etc.
  • Easy installation and configuration, also easy extension.
    • Good documentation.
    • Nice code.
  • I get what I expected.
    • Well, almost. See Pullquote section in “Read More”. Luckily I don’t think I am going to use it often. :D

Why Not Octopress?

  • False documentation.
    • In documentation’s example, everything looks fine, BUT,
    • Listed parameters for Codeblock/Backtick Code Block don’t work with fresh installed Octopress. More details listed in Codeblock section of this post.
  • I thought I would get what all Octopress.org has, I did NOT.
    • The parameters I just mentioned.
    • The theme I had on my octopress was also different from octopress.org.

More for the old post: Hello, Octopress! - Unit Test Plugins

Unit Test Plugins

Excerpts Plugin - The “Read on” button

Just add <!-- more --> anywhere you want.

Blockquote

Flying is learning how to throw yourself at the ground and miss.

Douglas AdamsThe Hichhikers Guide to the Galaxy

Pullquote - Well, Hexo is not that good at Pullquote

Surround your paragraph with the pull quote tags. Then when you come to
the text you want to pull, {“ surround it like this “} and that’s all there is to it.

Left-aligning pullquotes are good to alternate breaks in the text. They’re
{“ almost exactly like the default, “} right pullquotes, but a little different.

If this line is not here, any line right below the quote will start from the middle, like how this line does.

So after a pullquote, you need at least one line to keep things normal. Like this:

If this line is not here, any line right below the quote will start from the middle, like how this line does.

So after a pullquote, you need at least one line to keep things normal. Like this:

Codeblock

As you can see, start and mark don’t work here after a clean install of Octopress.

See here: BUG: start, mark, and linenos don’t work in code blocks.

Gist Tag

It looks different in Octopress from the documentation Gist Tag - Octopress

Backtick Code Block

Start and mark don’t work here either.
